content.raw: @sringer99 , you're right, the spring was acting in the opposite direction. [This](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-requests/235) patch in gazebo_models and [this](#!/osrf/srcsim/pull-requests/13) patch in srcsim should fix the issue. We'll release a new `srcsim` deb soon.
content.html: @sringer99 , you're right, the spring was acting in the opposite direction. This patch in gazebo_models and this patch in srcsim should fix the issue. We'll release a new srcsim deb soon.

content.html: With the changes in src_doorway/model.sdf the door pops open when the sim launches.

content.raw:
Erica,

Here is a command that I use all the time to find stuff.

find /opt -type f | grep -y qual2

Most of the stuff is in /opt/indigo or /opt/nasa.
content.html:
Erica,

content.raw: Erica, you're not bugging me, feel free to post any question. That file is not distributed, as we only distribute the `srcsim` headers, the srcsim shared libraries (`libQual1Plugin.so`, `libQual2Plugin.so`, and world files. This patch will be included in the next `srcsim` deb release.
content.html: Erica, you're not bugging me, feel free to post any question. That file is not distributed, as we only distribute the srcsim headers, the srcsim shared libraries (libQual1Plugin.so, libQual2Plugin.so, and world files. This patch will be included in the next srcsim deb release.

content.raw:
Is it possible to release just the plugin patch?  Right now the sim is working, but it is impossible to complete the task due to the button being backwards.  If an entire new srcsim deb is released, I am concerned that there will be bugs in there that have to be resolved and that costs another week, etc.
If you could just provide the plugin, we can move forward with the current build.
Alternatively, if you can give the details that [Jeremy White](https://bitbucket.org/knitfoo/) mentions, on just patching and doing the build ourselves, that would be OK.
content.html: Is it possible to release just the plugin patch? Right now the sim is working, but it is impossible to complete the task due to the button being backwards. If an entire new srcsim deb is released, I am concerned that there will be bugs in there that have to be resolved and that costs another week, etc. If you could just provide the plugin, we can move forward with the current build. Alternatively, if you can give the details that Jeremy White mentions, on just patching and doing the build ourselves, that would be OK.

content.raw: Dan, I simply followed the link that Carlos gave to a patch, followed that through to the source tree, which was easy to clone and patch, and then did a relatively naive c++ compile on the source code.  Unlike a lot of the other parts of this project, those files were very easy to build in a standalone fashion.
content.html: Dan, I simply followed the link that Carlos gave to a patch, followed that through to the source tree, which was easy to clone and patch, and then did a relatively naive c++ compile on the source code. Unlike a lot of the other parts of this project, those files were very easy to build in a standalone fashion.

content.raw:
@[Jeremy White](https://bitbucket.org/knitfoo/)  Thanks for the help.  I tried just compiling Qual2Plugin.cc with its header, providing paths to all the gazebo and sdf headers that Qual2Plugin.hh includes, but I get a  ton of errors such as this:

```
#!python

/usr/include/gazebo-7/gazebo/sensors/SensorTypes.hh: At global scope:
/usr/include/gazebo-7/gazebo/sensors/SensorTypes.hh:59:13: error: ‘shared_ptr’ in namespace ‘std’ does not name a type
     typedef std::shared_ptr<AltimeterSensor> AltimeterSensorPtr;
```
So I must be missing dependencies.  How did you determine what to link?

     typedef std::shared_ptr<AltimeterSensor> AltimeterSensorPtr;

content.raw:
off the top of my head, I believe it was something like this:
 g++ -shared -fpic -o libQual2Plugin.so -c `pkg-config --cflags gazebo` -I ../include Qual2Plugin.cc
content.html: off the top of my head, I believe it was something like this: g++ -shared -fpic -o libQual2Plugin.so -c pkg-config --cflags gazebo -I ../include Qual2Plugin.cc

content.raw:
[Jeremy White](https://bitbucket.org/knitfoo/) Using your help, I got it to compile; I was missing the gazebo dependency.  The new library is much larger than the old one, 679 KB for the new, 93 kb for the old.  I just replaced the old library with the new one in /opt/ros/indigo/lib  Unfortunately, it fails to load.  Permissions look OK, same as the original.  Is there anything else I needed to do?

```
#!python

[Err} [Plugin.hh:165] Failed to load plugin libQual2Plugin.so:  /opt/ros/indigo/lib/libQual2Plugin.so: only ET_DYN and ET_EXEC can be loaded
```
content.html:
Jeremy White Using your help, I got it to compile; I was missing the gazebo dependency. The new library is much larger than the old one, 679 KB for the new, 93 kb for the old. content.raw:
I am also planning to compile my own version if they do not have a official release soon. I have just been working on other stuff and have not got around to it. Anyway, I was planning on using the Tutorials from Gazebo to create the dev environment. The instructions for writing Gazebo plugins are here.

http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?cat=write_plugin

Hope that this helps.

content.raw:
[sringger99](https://bitbucket.org/sringer99/)  Great idea-- it works!  Compiling using the CMakelists.txt in the tutorial resulted in a library that was 488 KB,  still much bigger than the original one (93 KB), but smaller than the one I got with just the command line compile (679 KB).
The good news is that it works nicely, the door is closed at the start and opens when the button is pressed.
Thanks to [sringger99](https://bitbucket.org/sringer99/) and [Jeremy White](https://bitbucket.org/knitfoo/) for such good help on this one.
content.html: sringger99 Great idea-- it works! Compiling using the CMakelists.txt in the tutorial resulted in a library that was 488 KB, still much bigger than the original one (93 KB), but smaller than the one I got with just the command line compile (679 KB). The good news is that it works nicely, the door is closed at the start and opens when the button is pressed. Thanks to sringger99 and Jeremy White for such good help on this one.
